When I goe musing all alone,</br>Thinking of divers things sure knowne:</br>When I builde castles in the air,</br>Void of sorrow, and void of care,</br>Pleasing myself with phantasmes sweet,</br>Methinks the time runs verie sweet;</br>All my joyes to this are folly</br>None soe sweet as melancholy.

When I lye waking all alone</br>Thinking of divers things ill done,</br>My thoughts o'er me then tyrannize,</br>Fear and sorrow me surprize,</br>Whether I tarry still or go,</br>Methinks the time moves very slow;</br>All my joyes to this are folly,</br>Nought so sad as melancholy.

When to myself I act and smile,</br>With pleasing thoughts the time beguile,</br>By a brook side, or wood soe green,</br>Unheard, unsought for, and unseen,</br>A thousand pleasures do me bless</br>And crowne my soul with happiness;</br>All my joyes to this are folly,</br>Nought so sweet as melancholy.

When I lie, sit, or walk alone,</br>I sigh, I grieve, I make great moan,</br>In a dark grove, or irksome denn,</br>With discontents and furies, then</br>A thousand miseries at once</br>Mine heavy heart and soul entrance;</br>All my griefs to this are folly,</br>None so sowre as melancholy.

Methinks I hear, methinks I see</br>Sweet music, wondrous melody;</br>Towns, palaces, and cities fine,</br>Here now, then there, the world is mine,</br>Rare beauties, gallant ladies fine,</br>What e'er is lovely or divine:</br>All other joyes to this are folly,</br>Nought so sweet as melancholy.

Methinks I hear, methinks I see,</br>Ghosts, goblins, fiends, my phantasie</br>Presents a thousand ugly shapes,</br>Headless bears, black men, and apes,</br>Doleful outcries and fearful sight</br>My sad and dismal soul affright;</br>All my griefs to this are folly,</br>Nought so bad as melancholy.

Methinks I court, methinks I kiss,</br>Methinks I now embrace my mistress;</br>Ah!  blessed dayes, ah!  sweet content,</br>In Paradise my time is spent;</br>Let such thoughts still my fancie move,</br>So I may ever be in love:</br>All my joyes to this are folly,</br>Nought so sweet as melancholy.

When I recount love's many frights,</br>My sighs and tears, my waking nights,</br>My jealous fits, and mine hard fate,</br>I now repent, but 'tis too late;</br>No torment is so hard as love,</br>So bitter to my soul can prove:</br>All my griefs to this are folly,</br>None so harsh as melancholy.

Friends and companions get you gone,</br>'Tis my desire to be alone:</br>Ne'er well but when my thoughts and I</br>Do domineer in privacy;</br>No gem, no treasure like to this,</br>'Tis my delight, my crowne, my blisse:</br>All my joyes to this are folly,</br>Nought so sweet as melancholy.

'Tis my sole plague to be alone,</br>I am a beast, a monster grown,</br>I will nor light nor company,</br>I find it now my misery;</br>The scene is turn'd, my joyes are done,</br>Fear, discontent, and sorrows come;</br>Ah my griefs to this are folly,</br>None so fierce as melancholy.

I'll not change life with any king,</br>I ravish'd am, can the world bring</br>More joy than still to laugh and smile</br>In pleasant toyes time to beguile;</br>Doe not, ah!  do not trouble me,</br>So sweet content I feel, I see:</br>All my joyes to this are folly,</br>None so divine as melancholy.

I'll change my life with any wretch</br>Thou can'st from jayle or dunghill fetch;</br>My paine past cure, another hell,</br>I may not in this torment dwell;</br>Now, desparate I hate my life,</br>Lend me an halter, or a knife:</br>All my griefs to this are folly,</br>Nought so bad as melancholy.</br>
